awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ECS Fellows 2.0: Broadening Participation of Teachers and Students in Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Teach for America (TFA), in collaboration with the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) project team based at the University of Oregon, proposes to build on an existing collaboration -- the ECS Fellowship 1.0 -- that prepared in-service teachers from TFA's network to both advocate for broadened access to CS learning, and to teach an inquiry-based introductory CS course at high-need secondary schools. To date, the ECS Fellowship 1.0 project has prepared 46 TFA teachers from 11 urban and rural regions to teach the ECS course. That project also identified a number of barriers and obstacles that teachers face in advocating for CS instruction including principal de-prioritization of CS, and counselor bias. With the ECS Fellows 2.0 project, the team will shift its focus to understanding how best to recruit teachers of color to teach CS, support them in navigating the identified obstacles associated with advocating for CS in their schools, and help them to create equitable CS learning environments. 

ECS Fellows 2.0 will develop a networked improvement community (NIC) that centers on the experiences of teachers of color and their students while interrogating issues teachers consider central to broadening participation efforts. The project's goals are to: (1) establish a NIC made up of TFA staff, ECS staff, and teachers of color from TFA's network that constantly evolves to address problems of practice related to broadening participation in computing for teachers and students; (2) develop and share strategies that lead to increases in the number of CS teachers that identify as people of color from TFA's network; (3) identify necessary supports that help CS teachers introduce and expand CS learning opportunities for underrepresented students in high-need schools; and (4) identify strategies that CS teachers can use to create equitable CS learning environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Exploring Computer Science Fellows 2.0 (ECS Fellows 2.0) was a researcher-practitioner partnership (RPP) centered around better understanding the identities and experiences of CS teachers of color and includes Teach For America (Practitioner lead), University of Oregon (Research lead), and American Institutes for Research (Evaluation lead).

Participant Activities. Over the course of 2018 to 2022, we have engaged 1 TFA staff cohort and 3 cohorts of TFA secondary teachers in a variety of activities including the following:

  • We established one collaborative practitioner group of TFA staff. The staff-facing group (9 TFA staff across 6 placement regions) engaged in cycles designed to improve recruitment for CS teachers of color within TFA. 

  • We recruited three cohorts of TFA secondary teachers to become ECS Fellows. The teacher-facing cohorts focused on broadening CS student participation and included: 

    • 20 teachers across 13 TFA placement regions

    • 14 who identified as people of color

    • 11 who identified as coming from a low-income background

    • 12 who identified as female

  • We exposed teachers to a wide variety of professional development providers to develop their knowledge, orientations, and skills aligned not only to their CS development but towards their orientation in deepening equity in CS.

    • Some participants even engaged in a CS retreat at the Google campus in Mountain View, CA to collaboratively consider and design solutions around strengthening opportunities and equity in CS not only in their schools but in the broader system.

Select Research Activities and Findings. The project team engaged in research activities that uncovered some important findings, including:

  • We examined the experiences, perspectives, and standpoints of minoritized teachers in CS. We uncovered teachers’ motivations and dispositions that align with abolitionist teaching ideologies and pedagogies.

  • We found that recruitment of new CS teachers of color requires a multi-faceted approach that includes: understanding individual teacher motivations; how their background intersects with those motivations; understanding certification requirements; convincing school leaders to prioritize CS into the schedule; recruiting a course population that is representative of the student population; scheduling teacher PD; and providing ongoing support during the teacher’s first few years of teaching.

  • Additionally, we know that a shortage of K–12 computer science (CS) teachers leaves substantial gaps in students’ exposure to CS concepts and hinders the development of students’ interests and skills in CS. To address the shortage of K–12 CS teachers and a lack of gender and racial diversity among the CS teacher workforce, we sought to understand the factors that influence prospective teachers’ preferences to teach CS. To this end, we analyzed data from 27,700 prospective teacher applications accepted into the 2016-2020 TFA corps. Descriptive results show that earning at least one postsecondary CS credit is related to these prospective teachers’ preference to teach CS. This study also found that a larger proportion of male applicants and Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC) applicants earned a postsecondary CS credit, majored in CS, and preferred to teach CS compared with female applicants and White applicants, respectively.

    • When examining prospective teachers’ preferences to teach CS across gender and racial groups, our analysis found a number of relevant patterns. Specifically, the proportion of accepted male TFA applicants who preferred to teach CS is roughly double that of accepted female TFA applicants and those applicants who identified their gender as “other” (See Figure 1).  Moreover, the proportion of accepted BIPOC TFA applicants who preferred to teach CS is roughly 1.3 times greater than that of accepted White TFA applicants (See Figure 2). 

    • The study team also found a strong pattern between earning at least one postsecondary CS credit and preference to teach CS; specifically, the proportion of those accepted TFA applicants who preferred to teach CS is roughly 485 times greater among those who earned at least one postsecondary CS credit than among those who did not earn at least one postsecondary CS credit (See Figure 3).

    • A similar pattern was also found when examining those prospective teachers who earned postsecondary CS majors; the proportion of those accepted TFA applicants who preferred to teach CS is roughly 12 times greater among those who majored in CS than among those who did not major in CS (See Figure 4).


Last Modified: 12/08/2022
Modified by: Joanna Goode

por.por_txt_cntn:
Exploring Computer Science Fellows 2.0 (ECS Fellows 2.0) was a researcher-practitioner partnership (RPP) centered around better understanding the identities and experiences of CS teachers of color and includes Teach For America (Practitioner lead), University of Oregon (Research lead), and American Institutes for Research (Evaluation lead).
Participant Activities. Over the course of 2018 to 2022, we have engaged 1 TFA staff cohort and 3 cohorts of TFA secondary teachers in a variety of activities including the following:


We established one collaborative practitioner group of TFA staff. The staff-facing group (9 TFA staff across 6 placement regions) engaged in cycles designed to improve recruitment for CS teachers of color within TFA. 


We recruited three cohorts of TFA secondary teachers to become ECS Fellows. The teacher-facing cohorts focused on broadening CS student participation and included: 


20 teachers across 13 TFA placement regions


14 who identified as people of color


11 who identified as coming from a low-income background


12 who identified as female




We exposed teachers to a wide variety of professional development providers to develop their knowledge, orientations, and skills aligned not only to their CS development but towards their orientation in deepening equity in CS.


Some participants even engaged in a CS retreat at the Google campus in Mountain View, CA to collaboratively consider and design solutions around strengthening opportunities and equity in CS not only in their schools but in the broader system.




Select Research Activities and Findings. The project team engaged in research activities that uncovered some important findings, including:


We examined the experiences, perspectives, and standpoints of minoritized teachers in CS. We uncovered teachers’ motivations and dispositions that align with abolitionist teaching ideologies and pedagogies.


We found that recruitment of new CS teachers of color requires a multi-faceted approach that includes: understanding individual teacher motivations; how their background intersects with those motivations; understanding certification requirements; convincing school leaders to prioritize CS into the schedule; recruiting a course population that is representative of the student population; scheduling teacher PD; and providing ongoing support during the teacher’s first few years of teaching.


Additionally, we know that a shortage of K–12 computer science (CS) teachers leaves substantial gaps in students’ exposure to CS concepts and hinders the development of students’ interests and skills in CS. To address the shortage of K–12 CS teachers and a lack of gender and racial diversity among the CS teacher workforce, we sought to understand the factors that influence prospective teachers’ preferences to teach CS. To this end, we analyzed data from 27,700 prospective teacher applications accepted into the 2016-2020 TFA corps. Descriptive results show that earning at least one postsecondary CS credit is related to these prospective teachers’ preference to teach CS. This study also found that a larger proportion of male applicants and Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC) applicants earned a postsecondary CS credit, majored in CS, and preferred to teach CS compared with female applicants and White applicants, respectively.


When examining prospective teachers’ preferences to teach CS across gender and racial groups, our analysis found a number of relevant patterns. Specifically, the proportion of accepted male TFA applicants who preferred to teach CS is roughly double that of accepted female TFA applicants and those applicants who identified their gender as "other" (See Figure 1).  Moreover, the proportion of accepted BIPOC TFA applicants who preferred to teach CS is roughly 1.3 times greater than that of accepted White TFA applicants (See Figure 2). 


The study team also found a strong pattern between earning at least one postsecondary CS credit and preference to teach CS; specifically, the proportion of those accepted TFA applicants who preferred to teach CS is roughly 485 times greater among those who earned at least one postsecondary CS credit than among those who did not earn at least one postsecondary CS credit (See Figure 3).


A similar pattern was also found when examining those prospective teachers who earned postsecondary CS majors; the proportion of those accepted TFA applicants who preferred to teach CS is roughly 12 times greater among those who majored in CS than among those who did not major in CS (See Figure 4).
